metadata.title: CVE-2018-10852 on Ubuntu 22.04 LTS (jammy) - low
metadata.description:
The UNIX pipe which sudo uses to contact SSSD and read the available sudorules from SSSD has too wide permissions, which means that anyone who cansend a message using the same raw protocol that sudo and SSSD use can readthe sudo rules available for any user. This affects versions of SSSD before1.16.3.

    Update Instructions:

    Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2018-10852` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
    by updating your system to the following package versions:

libipa-hbac0 - 2.2.2-1
libnss-sss - 2.2.2-1
libpam-sss - 2.2.2-1
libsss-certmap0 - 2.2.2-1
libsss-idmap0 - 2.2.2-1
libsss-nss-idmap0 - 2.2.2-1
libsss-simpleifp0 - 2.2.2-1
libsss-sudo - 2.2.2-1
libwbclient-sssd - 2.2.2-1
python3-libipa-hbac - 2.2.2-1
python3-libsss-nss-idmap - 2.2.2-1
python3-sss - 2.2.2-1
sssd - 2.2.2-1
sssd-ad - 2.2.2-1
sssd-ad-common - 2.2.2-1
sssd-common - 2.2.2-1
sssd-dbus - 2.2.2-1
sssd-ipa - 2.2.2-1
sssd-kcm - 2.2.2-1
sssd-krb5 - 2.2.2-1
sssd-krb5-common - 2.2.2-1
sssd-ldap - 2.2.2-1
sssd-proxy - 2.2.2-1
sssd-tools - 2.2.2-1
No subscription required

criterions.comment: sssd package in jammy, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '2.2.2-1').
